title: A decade after Paris - ECCO Climate
description:
Not enough, but far better That global emissions are still edging up hides half the story.
Emissions are growing far more slowly than in the decade before Paris and China’s emissions have been flat or declining since 2024.
The world economy is shifting, and the political and legal clarity that the Paris Agreement consensus provided is at the root of this transformation.
Fortunately, we don’t need another Paris Agreement moment.
The fossil fuel transition roadmap and pledges launched alongside the formal COP30 decisions follow this trend.
text:
Ten years after the adoption of the Paris Agreement, the data tells a clear story: the world has not yet done enough to secure the global warming limit of 1.5C, but it has changed direction in ways few thought possible in 2015. What do we need from the next ten years to complete the job?

Not enough, but far better

That global emissions are still edging up hides half the story. Emissions are growing far more slowly than in the decade before Paris and China’s emissions have been flat or declining since 2024. Clean energy investment is at record levels and now outpaces fossil fuel investment by roughly two to one after reaching parity six years ago. Electrotech is driving growth in major economies and with renewable energy the cheapest and fastest energy source to deploy, non‑fossil sources already provide over 41% of the global energy mix. In 2015, we all predicted this scale of change would take until the mid‑2030s.

The world economy is shifting, and the political and legal clarity that the Paris Agreement consensus provided is at the root of this transformation. The latest round of national climate plans, the crux of the Paris Agreement architecture, still adds up to a pathway of 2.3-2.5 degrees of warming, but they do represent plans that will see emissions drop by at least 12% on 2019 levels by 2035. Countries just agreed in Belém that they should continue ramping up that ambition and – critically – develop implementation and investment plans to make sure it’s delivered. But the overwhelming message from commentators and analysts in response to the Belem COP30 result was “failure”.

Is there a future in which the shaky ground of multilateral cooperation can get us onto that 1.5C warming limit pathway? And are COPs the “least-worst system”, as the UK Energy Secretary Ed Miliband put it, to get there?

Politics in a “down phase”, trajectory still up

Politically, the last decade has been anything but linear. There have been high points – the adoption of the Paris rulebook, the net zero pledging bonanza of COP26, the first mention of fossil fuels in a globally agreed climate decision, the tripling‑renewables and doubling‑efficiency goals, and the launch of loss and damage funding arrangements. There have also been very visible setbacks, including major emitters backtracking, growing climate polarisation and heavily contested COP outcomes. This ebb and flow is one we have become accustomed to.

But the trajectory of climate action has remained upwards. Since 2015, climate framework laws have more than tripled, climate policy instruments have increased roughly seven‑fold and around three‑quarters of global GDP (rising to just over four‑fifths including sub‑national pledges) remains covered by some form of net‑zero target, even after the retreat of the US federal goal.

Our political “down” phase today is complicated by a more difficult and different geopolitical environment. Climate diplomacy now unfolds amid wars, deepening strategic rivalry, reshoring of supply chains, and intensified competition over critical minerals and industrial policy. International cooperation is shifting away from multilateral frameworks towards a more explicitly bilateral and transactional model, centred on packages of energy, infrastructure and security deals. This direction is reflected in ACS2 outcomes, the EU’s revamped Global Gateway strategy (and, in its extreme version, the latest US national security strategy.). While this can leave space for mutual interest, investment and agency for partner countries, it also risks shortening political time horizons, fragmenting standards and weakening incentives to invest in governance and social safeguards.

The future of the COP space

Against this backdrop, frustration with the COP process is understandable. The system is overloaded. The expectations are enormous. And we are still far from where science – and people on the frontline of climate impacts – say we need to be. Fossil fuel subsidies remain pervasive while adaptation and loss –and damage support lag, deepening existing inequalities, with disproportionate burdens on low-income households, marginalised communities and workers in carbon-intensive sectors.

We are right to question whether COPs are the right place to address this crisis. But COPs are not sentient actors that “fail” or “succeed” on their own. They are (precious) political and institutional spaces that deliver only what governments, institutions and societies choose to invest in them – in terms of ambition, negotiating capital and implementation capacity.

Big results like the Paris Agreement demand a huge diplomatic lift and just the right convergence of political conditions, that are clearly not in place now (as the latest IMO talks on shipping emissions showed). Fortunately, we don’t need another Paris Agreement moment. We have a permanent global architecture with five yearly cycles of countries sharing their nationally determined climate plans followed by collective global stocktakes and an ‘Action Agenda’ for driving the action of non-state actors like businesses and city governments.

The climate ambitious are already evolving how they use the COP space, adapting to the new mission for implementation. Recent years have seen coalitions of the willing on issues such as grids, storage and methane effectively compel Presidencies to create room for outcome documents, roadmaps and Presidency‑led initiatives that go beyond the minimum consensus text. The fossil fuel transition roadmap and pledges launched alongside the formal COP30 decisions follow this trend. This model could become a disciplined tool for implementation, if it can transform layers of pledges into actual policy frameworks.

Designing the next phase of climate governance in a new world order

The bigger test is whether these new COP tools can stand up to our evolving geopolitical landscape. This will require addressing the material constraints facing most of the world, above all debt and access to capital. For many emerging and developing economies, climate ambition is constrained not by lack of plans or ambition but by high borrowing costs, limited fiscal space and inadequate volumes of concessional and grant finance. It will also depend on finding ways to integrate trade, industrial and climate governance. A fossil fuel transition roadmap, for example, would need to convince states that they will have routes to prosperity outside their fossil fuel extraction models: clearly addressing the risks and providing economic feasible alternatives backed by international financial tools to enable them. A big ask in a geopolitical maelstrom.

Nonetheless, the entry into force of the UN High Seas Treaty in 2025 shows that states can still agree ambitious rules for protecting global commons even in a period of heightened international tension. Currently, major countries from the Global South are openly pushing back against anti-multilateral approaches to climate and energy, arguing instead for an international order based on shared rules rather than bilateral power-plays. Indonesian President Probowo’s UN General Assembly speech rallied a defense of multilateralism in stark contrast to US President Trump’s tirade. At April’s IEA Energy Security Conference, the US’ push to resurrect the fossil economy was met with defiance from energy transition allies. The evolving geopolitical order is not yet doomed to a fortress world.

The biggest strategic question for the next ten years is thus whether climate cooperation can become a structuring element of a new global order, rather than a casualty of its disorder. Can west, east and south define a shared floor of responsibility and support, even as they compete on technology and industrial capacity?
